note: These practice questions are interspersed within the tutorial slides for immediate practice.

questions.questionText: If A can complete a work in 12 days, what fraction of work can he complete in 3 days?
questions.explanation: Work done by A in 1 day = 1/12. Work done in 3 days = 3 × (1/12) = 3/12 = 1/4 of the total work.

questions.questionText: A can complete a work in 15 days and B can complete it in 10 days. If both work together, how many days will it take to complete the work?
questions.explanation: Using the formula: Time = (a × b)/(a + b) = (15 × 10)/(15 + 10) = 150/25 = 6 days. Or using LCM method: LCM(15,10) = 30. A's efficiency = 2, B's efficiency = 3, Combined = 5. Time = 30/5 = 6 days.

questions.questionText: A can complete a work in 20 days. After working for 5 days, B joins him and they complete the remaining work in 9 days. In how many days can B alone complete the work?
questions.explanation: Total work = 20 units. A's efficiency = 1 unit/day. Work done by A in 5 days = 5 units. Remaining = 15 units. (A+B) complete 15 units in 9 days, so (A+B)'s efficiency = 15/9 = 5/3 units/day. B's efficiency = 5/3 - 1 = 2/3 units/day. Time for B alone = 20 ÷ (2/3) = 30 days.

questions.questionText: A pipe can fill a tank in 12 hours and another pipe can empty it in 18 hours. If both pipes are opened together, in how many hours will the tank be filled?
questions.explanation: Filling rate = 1/12 per hour. Emptying rate = 1/18 per hour. Net filling = 1/12 - 1/18 = 3/36 - 2/36 = 1/36 per hour. Time to fill = 36 hours.
